awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Hai-Lung Dai of Temple University is studying how bacterial membranes regulate their interactions with the surrounding environment, in particular those containing antimicrobial agents.  The goal of this project is to provide fundamental knowledge that holds potential for future development of more effective antimicrobials that destroy disease-causing bacteria and reduce bacterial resistance to antibiotics.  The role of small molecules and synthetic proteins in changing the permeability of bacterial cell membranes will be studied by quantitatively examining the response of small molecules whose interaction with light allows for their very sensitive detection when bound to cell membrane components.  This powerful light-based method will be used to test how tiny holes are formed in the membrane upon membrane interaction with nearby chemicals or by changing how molecules move through channels in the membrane of bacteria.  Professor Dai will integrate high school, college, and PhD students into the research program, providing a highly diverse group of students a very broad scientific skill set to help them pursue their career goals.  Further broadening the impact of the project is a summer camp for Philadelphia inner city middle school students.  In sum, the project will help strengthen the scientific workforce by training and exposing young minds to research aimed at providing answers to important fundamental questions about the chemistry of bacterial membranes with the ultimate goal of providing information key to addressing bacterial infections and antibiotic resistance.  The significance of the research area is evidenced by the growing problem of antimicrobial-resistant bacterial infections, which are predicted by the World Health Organization and the United Nations to result in the death of 10 million people annually by 2050. 

In this study, Professor Dai will examine how the complex wall structures of bacteria exercise their regulatory functions on external molecules like antimicrobials.  We will delineate, using both nonlinear optical spectroscopy and microscopy approaches, a variety of membrane transport mechanisms.  These will include those based on import channels, efflux pumps, and lipid bilayer permeability, which play key roles in regulating intracellular concentrations of molecules critical to bacteria viability and protecting the bacteria from harmful compounds or an over-abundance of what would otherwise be thought to be useful compounds.  The research will provide fundamental understanding of how antimicrobials interact with the various components of bacterial membranes to make them more permeable and reduce the protective functions of the membrane. Experiments will be designed to gather data critical for understanding how membranes perform their regulatory functions for living cells, as well as for designing strategies for developing more effective antimicrobials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit: Second Harmonic Light Scattering (SHS) Probe of Molecular Interactions with Biological Membranes Probing molecular interactions with membranes of living biological cells has been an important scientific endeavor over the past several decades. Current methodologies have enabled the observation of membrane transport of macromolecules or ions but for small molecules like drugs their transport remains a challenge for experimental probe. This is particularly the case for cells with multiple membranes such as bacteria. Over the last decade we have shown that Second Harmonic Light Scattering (SHS) can be used to observe real-time adsorption and transport of small/medium size molecules through living cell membranes. For bacteria, this method allows the observation of adsorption and transport of molecules at each individual membrane within the wall structure. Shown in the nearby figure is the time-resolved SHS intensity recorded following the addition of bacteria E. coli into a solution containing the hydrophobic cation, malachite green (MG). It revealed sequential adsorption and transport of MG at the bacteria outer (the 1st peak) and inner (the 2nd peak) membranes in real time.

 

SHS has enabled us to examine a variety of structural and biochemical factors influencing membrane transport, as well as how membrane-molecule interactions, including antimicrobials with bacterial membranes, affect cell functions: (the italics parts were results specifically from this grant)

  • Membrane structure greatly affects molecular transport rate. Transport of MG through porin channels is two orders of magnitude faster than passive diffusion through the lipid bilayers. In contrast, the tightly packed murine erythroleukemia cell wall does not allow MG to penetrate through. Phase transition in membranes also induces vast changes in diffusive transport rates.
  • When applied for imaging, SHS can be used to map passive molecular transport rate through the membrane of single cells with regional specificity.
  • The adsorption density of a hydrophobic ion can be used to quantitatively determine charge density of the surface of the cell membrane.
  • The unique transport behavior of CV explained the mechanism of the century-old Gram bacterial differentiation. This work was publicized in C&ENews and Science Digest.
  • Molecular structure greatly affects the transport rate. MG, Brilliant Green (BG), and Crystal Violet (CV) all belong to the mildly antimicrobial triphenylmethane group which has been widely used as bacterial staining dyes. MG and BG have large permanent dipoles, while CV does not. BG has the highest lipophilicity. On the other hand, CV has the most hydrogen bonding sites. It was observed that BG and MG permeate through lipid bilayers, while CV does not. Their transport rates correlate with trends in lipophilicity, dipole moment, and the number of hydrogen bonding sites.
  • The action of mechanosensitive channels in living cells was characterized in real time.
  • The influence of environmentally rich molecules such as the bacterial signaling molecule indole (see journal cover article illustrated in the nearby figure) on bacterial membrane permeability has been revealed.
  • The disruptive effect of antibiotics such as azithromycin and brilacidin on the membranes of Gram-negative E. coli was characterized.

 

The above accomplishments illustrate a new capability that can be broadly applied to quantitatively observe molecular interactions at membranes of living cells with complex membrane structures.

 

Broader Impact: Applications in Medical and Biological Studies, and Education The application of SHS to living cells has the potential of solving a broad range of problems related to molecular transport through membranes. The following ongoing collaborations illustrate the broader interests of the biological and medical communities: William DeGrado (UCSF) on the effect of peptide based antimicrobials on membrane functions, Glenn Gerhard (Temple U Medical School) on molecular adsorption and transport through cancerous versus normal human cells, Rosa Maria Sanz (U Oviedo, Spain) on adsorption and transport of melatonin at human cell membranes, and Oscar Ruiz (AFRL) on the function of efflux pumps of bacteria in fuel-rich environments. 

 

During this grant period, we have applied for a patent for using SHS for accurate differentiation of single bacterial cells. This patent has been licensed for commercial development of an instrument (a Ti-Saphire laser plus a microscope) for routine, turn-key differentiation of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.

 

Students and postdoctoral researchers engaging in research described here were exposed to not only state-of-the-art techniques, but also to an intellectually broad range of disciplines. At least two of the former postdocs have taken academic positions (Max Planck and Utah State) and one in national labs (PNNL). Five PhD graduates have taken postdoctoral positions (two in medical schools) and industrial jobs. Over the last five years, there have been at least five undergraduate students participating in research through the Dai lab; almost all of them have gone on to graduate schools.
